content:
• Thursday, September 22, 2016
  • TWER

    New building additions rising 70% from Q2 for Towerstream

    • Fixed wireless firm Towerstream (TWER +6.2%) said today it would add 70 new buildings to its On-Net footprint in Q3, ending next week.
    • That's a 70% boost to new additions from Q2, and brings total buildings to 335 (and total number of businesses in those buildings to more than 10,000, up 30% Q/Q).
    • Average monthly revenue for those buildings is $1,102, with a building penetration rate of 6%.
    • Meanwhile, the company closed its public offering of stock for about $4M in gross proceeds. Shares were sold at $1.35, and the underwriter has a 45-day option to by up to 444,444 more shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:05 PM | 9 Comments
  • T

    AT&T extends carriage deal with Scripps Networks

    • Add to the rack of retransmission deals that AT&T's (T +1.3%) striking with content creators one with Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI +2.8%), the TV home of HGTV, Food Network, DIY, Cooking Channel, Travel Channel and more.
    • As with the spate of recent deals the wireless giant has been setting, it not only extends distribution on DirecTV (and U-verse) for several years, but covers the expanded digital rights that include the networks on upcoming DirecTV streaming services (particularly DirecTV Now).
    • DirecTV Now launches in Q4 with more than 100 channels and what AT&T chief Randall Stephenson calls a "very, very aggressive price point" and data-cap exemptions for AT&T wireless subscribers.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:53 PM | 6 Comments
  • BATS

    BATS Global Markets jumps 24% on report CBOE in talks to buy

    • BATS Global Markets (BATS:BATS) is up 24.2% after hours on Bloomberg reports that CBOE Holdings (CBOE -0.5%) is in talks to buy the company.
    • That might make an exchange group with a market value of near $8.3B.
    • After hours: CBOE +0.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:43 PM | 2 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: MIFI +30.4%. IMPV +12.9%. ACRX +4.7%. AIR +2.8%. IAG +2.6%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: CXRX-OLD -3.8%. SCS -2.6%. TWTR -2.5%. CAFD -2.4%. CNHI -2.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:36 PM
  • BRCD

    Brocade extends retention deals with leadership team

    • Brocade Communications (BRCD +1.9%) has extended change-of-control retention agreements with its executive team for another three years.
    • The deals in particular cover CEO Lloyd Carney; Chief Technology Officer Ken Cheng; Chief Operating Officer Gale England; Chief Financial Officer Daniel Fairfax; and Senior VP of Worldwide Sales Jeffrey Lindholm.
    • Those original deals were set to expire next month, but were extended until Nov. 2, 2019, likely the last day of fiscal 2019 for Brocade.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:25 PM
  • ENPH

    Enphase Energy rolls out restructuring, cost reduction initiatives

    • Enphase Energy (NASDAQ:ENPH) -17.9% AH after announcing restructuring and cost reduction initiatives resulting in ~$20M in annualized savings.
    • ENPH says it will reduce ~11% of its global workforce and eliminate certain non-core projects, and expects to incur ~$3M in total restructuring charges during Q3.
    • ENPH reaffirms Q3 revenue guidance of $87M-$93M vs. $89M analyst consensus estimate, and sets Q4 revenue guidance of $90M-$100M vs. $91.9M consensus.
    • ENPH also plans a common stock offering of undetermined size.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:14 PM | 47 Comments
  • IMPV

    Imperva +15% after hours on reported IBM, Cisco interest [updated]

    • Imperva (NASDAQ:IMPV) disclosed previously it had retained Qatalyst Partners to review strategic alternatives subsequent reports the company was considering a potential sale.
    • Talk now circulating has IBM, Cisco and possibly others looking to make a move.
    • Update (9/23 4:07PM ET): Bloomberg reported the above-mentioned names as having expressed interest in addition to Forcepoint (NYSE:RTN) and Akamai Technologies (NASDAQ:AKAM). Though no deals materialized today, Imperva shares are nonetheless holding a 20%+ upswing on the report into the weekend.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:01 PM | 6 Comments
  • CAFD

    8point3 Energy to launch 7M-share offering

    • 8point3 Energy (NASDAQ:CAFD) -4.3% AH after announcing a 7M-share public offering, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 1.05M class A shares.
    • CAFD says it plans to use the proceeds to fund part of the previously announced purchase of a 49% interest in the Henrietta solar project in Kings County, Calif.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:54 PM | 30 Comments
  • TWTR

    Twitter downgraded to Underperform at RBC Capital Markets; -2.5% after hours

    • Moves from previously rated Sector Perform.
    • Price target lowered from $17 to $14 ($18.21 after hours).
    • Mark Mahaney: "This change is based on our belief that Twitter’s value proposition to advertisers could be waning, based on our recent advertiser survey data. We note that we still believe Twitter is a unique asset with a strong value proposition to core users."
    • Further cites uncertainty on Twitter's (NYSE:TWTR) user and usage acceleration, various channel checks and concern resulting from the above-referenced ad spend surveys and others previously conducted.
    • The downgrade comes as the company is set to stream its second of ten Thursday Night Football games later tonight.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:39 PM | 67 Comments
  • PLNT

    Planet Fitness insiders prepare for sale

    • Certain existing owners of Planet Fitness (NYSE:PLNT) intend to sell 8M shares of Class A stock pursuant to a shelf offering filed earlier this month.
    • The company will receive no proceeds from the sale.
    • Shares -2.5% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:37 PM | 13 Comments
  • RHT

    Red Hat sentiment largely positive on Q2 earnings

    • UBS (Buy), BMO Capital Markets (Outperform), Raymond James (Outperform) and Drexel Hamilton (Buy) raise respective targets on Red Hat (NYSE:RHT) to $90, $89, $90 and $110 (current price $80.02). Oppenheimer & Co. restates an Outperform, maintaining an $88 target.
    • Jefferies analyst John DiFucci raises his target from $75 to $79, though retains a Hold rating while MKM Partners' Kevin Buttigieg is mostly unmoved on the results, restating a Neutral rating and $75 target (raises FY 2017 revenue estimate to $2.43B and EPS estimate to $2.25).
    • Earnings call transcript
    • Q2 overview
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM | 1 Comment
  • QRTEA

    Liberty Interactive rebounds as CEO Maffei sees 'green shoots'

    • Liberty Interactive (QVCA +5%, LVNTA +1.9%) is on the climb today after CEO Greg Maffei suggested a turnaround in the company's revenue (and share price) fortunes.
    • "We don't see any evidence of continuing declines below this level," Maffei said at the Communacopia Conference today. "In fact, we see some green shoots, suggesting upside."
    • Shares of QVCA are down 28.5% YTD -- much of that coming after a Q2 earnings report where it noted growth falling off in the U.S.
    • Asked about the company's discount to HSN (HSNI +2.9%) -- of which Liberty Interactive owns 38% -- Maffei says some may think Liberty may buy out HSN "at a big number," but denies that will happen.
    • “If the numbers are right, we’ll do it, but we’re not gonna do it at some crazy multiple," Maffei says.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:56 PM
  • TOT

    Total outlines further cuts in investments, operating costs

    • Total (TOT +2.5%) will continue to cut capital spending and operating costs while raising production, CEO Patrick Pouyanné tells investors.
    • Pouyanné says TOT plans to cut its investment to $15B-$17B in 2017, down from an expected $18B-$19B this year, and sets up a target to cut costs by more than $4B in 2018, up from more than $2.4B expected this year and more than $3B targeted in 2017.
    • Despite increased cost-savings and lower investment, the CEO says TOT will lift output by 5%/year until 2020 and by 1%-2% annually thereafter, as it counts mainly on the projects it has invested in before oil prices collapsed and it started cutting on investment.
    • The announcement, while not a surprise, will raise investor interest in TOT, which has not performed significantly better than peers despite its operational outperformance, Macquarie says.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:47 PM | 2 Comments
  • SCHL

    Scholastic +2.7% after revenues grow across board

    • Scholastic (NASDAQ:SCHL) opened to the downside today, but has since climbed to a 1.9% gain after posting fiscal Q1 earnings where it managed a better loss than expected despite a revenue miss.
    • Revenues grew 48%, however, with growth across all three of its segments, with large thanks to the release of Harry Potter and the Cursed Child Parts One and Two, in a quarter "not significant for book clubs and book fairs" with school not in session.
    • Late in Q2, the company expects a boost from the release of the screenplay of Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them by Potter author J.K. Rowling.
    • Operating loss improved to $63.1M from a year-ago loss of $79.5M.
    • Revenue by segment: Children's Book Publishing and Distribution, $137.8M (up 104%); Education, $55.2M (up 10%); International, $89.7M (up 23%).
    • The company affirmed its fiscal 2017 outlook, for revenue of $1.7B-$1.8B (vs. consensus for $1.773B) and EPS from continuing operations of $1.60-$1.70 (vs. expected $1.66). It's forecasting free cash flow of $40M-$50M.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:41 PM
  • LCI

    Lannett scientific chief bids adieu; shares ease 5%

    • Lannett Company (LCI -4.7%) slumps on double normal volume in apparent response to the news that chief of scientific affairs Mahendra Dedhiya, Ph.D., will resign effective October 21 to take a faculty position at Long Island University. He joined Lannett last year as part of the Silarx Pharmaceuticals acquisition.
    • A search for a new head of R&D is underway.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:36 PM | 33 Comments
  • HLUKF

    Lundbeck's Alzheimer's candidate idalopirdine flunks late-stage study; shares off 13%; ripple effect takes Axovant down 11%

    • Lundbeck A/S (OTC:HLUKF)(OTCPK:HLUYY) slumps 13% on light volume in response to its announcement that a Phase 3 clinical trial, STARSHINE, assessing idalopirdine for the treatment of mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's disease (AD) failed to achieve its primary endpoint of a statistically valid reduction in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-cognitive subscale (ADAS-cog) total score when added to donepezil (Eisai's ARICEPT). In addition, idalopirdine failed to beat placebo in the secondary endpoints. On the plus side, idalopirdine was safe and well tolerated. The disappointing results failed to confirm the positive data generated in mid-stage studies.
    • Two ongoing Phase 3 trials, STARBEAM and STARBRIGHT, will continue as planned. Top-line data are expected in Q1 2017.
    • Idalopirdine is a selective 5-HT6 antagonist. The 5-HT6 receptor is expressed almost exclusively in the brain, specifically in regions involved in cognition.
    • Fellow AD drug developer Axovant Sciences (AXON -10.5%) is down on pessimism that its Phase 3 study, MINDSET, of similar drug intepirdine will succeed since it has the same primary endpoint.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:30 PM | 6 Comments
  • AABA

    Verizon: Knew about Yahoo breach in past two days, watching probe

    • In a statement, Verizon (VZ +1.2%) -- set for a $4.83B deal to acquire Yahoo (YHOO) -- says it was aware of the latter's giant security breach in the past two days.
    • "We understand that Yahoo is conducting an active investigation of this matter, but we otherwise have limited information and understanding of the impact," the telecom said in a statement tweeted out by an account for Bob Varettoni of Verizon PR.
    • "We will evaluate as the investigation continues through the lens of overall Verizon interests, including consumers, customers, shareholders and related communities. Until then, we are not in position to further comment."
    • Yahoo this hour has confirmed that a late-2014 breach resulted in stolen user information that Yahoo believes affects 500M user accounts. Its shares, up as much as 1.7% earlier, have turned negative, -0.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:05 PM | 32 Comments

  • Technology - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 3:00 pm

    • Gainers: HTCH +166%. OTC:FNCX +19%. FORM +11%. PTI +10%. HEAR +10%.
    • Losers: NETE -6%. JBL -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM
  • SCWX

    Cybersecurity trading up on Yahoo data breach

    • Yahoo has confirmed a breach affecting at least 500M of its users and SecureWorks (SCWX +6.9%) FireEye (FEYE +5.1%), Barracuda Networks (CUDA +2.9%), Palo Alto Networks (PANW +1.8%), Fortinet (FTNT +1.4%), Imperva (IMPV +1.2%), CyberArk Software (CYBR +1%) and others are benefitting because of it.
    • The impact of the development on Yahoo has so far been minimal, with shares presently trading up 0.6% on the day.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:59 PM

  • Energy/Materials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: SAEX +42%. PACD +10%. LEU +9%. PQ +10%. NE +6%.
    • Losers: OMN -15%. HGT-OLD -8%. FTK -8%. VGZ -6%. FUL -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:10 PM
  • JBL

    Jabil Circuit -5% post-earnings, Needham & Company downgrades to Hold

    • Jabil Circuit (JBL -5.4%) posted better-than-expected Q4 results while announcing a restructuring plan expected to cost $195M over the next two years.
    • Analyst Sean Hannan, on the report, downgrades from a previous Buy rating citing customer sell-through uncertainty and fairly valued shares. Does note positives involving Nypro, EMS and a consistent position regarding its relationship with Apple.
    • The rating adjustment contrasts with a more confident tone struck by UBS prior to yesterday's earnings release.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:08 PM
  • TTOO

    T2 Biosystems up 13% on Canon stake

    • Thinly traded micro cap T2 Biosystems (TTOO +13.4%) breaks out of consolidation on 80% higher volume, albeit on turnover of only 295K shares, in response to its announcement that Canon U.S.A. has established a $40M equity stake in the company via a direct purchase of common shares at $6.56, Tuesday's closing price.
    • T2 has been collaborating with Canon on the development of Lyme disease products since February 2015. It expects to file a marketing application in the U.S. in mid-2017 seeking approval of its T2Bacteria Panel.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:06 PM | 2 Comments

  • Financials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 1:00 PM

    • Gainers: HGSH +9%. CORR +8%. TREE +6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:01 PM | 21 Comments
  • NVLN

    Aegerion and Collegium Pharma stake their claim to the biotech bull party; shares up again today

    • Thinly traded nano cap Aegerion Pharmaceuticals (AEGR +20.7%) shows some zip today on more than six times normal volume. Shares have almost doubled in less than two weeks. Last quarter, product sales were down almost 31% after the company pulled top seller JUXTAPID (lomitapide) from the EU and certain other markets due to the lack of traction. In June, it announced a merger with QLT which should be consummated next quarter. It will do business as Novelion Therapeutics thereafter. It expects marketing approval for lomitapide in Japan by year end.
    • Thinly traded micro cap Collegium Pharmaceuticals (COLL +20.4%) perks up on more than a 5x surge in volume. Like AEGR, shares have rallied almost 80% this month. In May, the company nabbed the U.S. rights to BioDelivery Sciences' (BDSI +0.8%) pain med ONSOLIS (fentanyl buccal soluble film). The month before, the FDA approved its abuse-deterrent oxycodone Xtampza ER. Preparations for market launch are in process.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:54 PM | 2 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: HTCH +166%. WCIC +38%. AVXL +23%. SAEX +21%. AEGR +21%. NM +21%. COLL +20%. TWER +17%. DSX +16%. WVE +15%.
    • Losers: AXON -15%. OMN -14%. GBSN -13%. LBIX-OLD -10%. EBIO -9%. SORL -9%. KURA -8%. RGSE -8%. MDGS -8%. HGT-OLD -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:44 PM | 1 Comment
  • AVXL

    Anavex 2-73 shows Parkinson's treatment potential in preclinical study; shares up 26%

    • Micro cap Anavex Life Sciences (AVXL +25.7%) heads north on more than a 6x surge in volume in apparent response to its announcement of preclinical data that suggests product candidate ANAVEX 2-73 may have potential in treating Parkinson's disease (PD). The company says results from a mouse model of PD showed improvements in all measures, including behavioral, histopathological and neuroinflammatory endpoints. The data are being presented in a poster session at the World Parkinson Congress 2016 in Portland, OR.
    • CEO Chris Missling, Ph.D., says, " This initial data is encouraging, and together with already available clinical safety and tolerability data on ANAVEX 2-73, might accelerate the exploration of ANAVEX 2-73 as a potential therapeutic intervention in Parkinson's disease."
    • Orally available ANAVEX 2-73 is a sigma-1 receptor (S1R) agonist. S1Rs play a key role in the modulation of neurotransmission. It is currently in Phase 2 development for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM | 10 Comments

  • Consumer Goods - Top Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm

    • Gainers: SCS +11%. GPRO +9%. HY +7%. SYUT +6%.
    • Losers: LBIX-OLD -13%. MLHR -8%. SORL -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:00 PM
  • BAM

    Brookfield Asset surges after RBC upgrade

    • "Brookfield Asset Management's (BAM +5.1%) competitive advantages include global reach, size/scale, strong investment track records, and multiple funds/strategies,” says analyst Neil Downey, upgrading to Top Pick from Outperform.
    • The company has grown and diversified its client base, which now includes 425 global private fund investors vs. 320 a year ago, and fee-bearing capital of $108B is up 15% from a year ago. Downey, however, expects that to slow in the next 12-24 months before reaccelerating in 2019 and 2020.
    • By Downey's estimate, BAM has intrinsic value of $38 per share, and he has a $41 price target.
    • Previously: Brookfield Asset made a Top Pick at RBC (Sept. 22)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:49 AM | 2 Comments
  • GLMD

    Galmed Pharma readies Phase 1/2 study of Aramchol in kids with NAFLD; shares up 13%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Galmed Pharmaceuticals (GLMD +13.1%) enjoys the NASH rally stoked by Allergan's (AGN +1.7%) generous acquisition of Tobira Therapeutics (TBRA +0.9%). Shares have rallied over 46% in a week.
    • Today, the company announced that it inked an agreement with the UC-San Diego School of Medicine to conduct a Phase 1/2 study, ARTISAN, assessing Aramchol in a juvenile population with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The trial is expected to commence in H1 2017.
    • Aramchol, a conjugate of cholic acid and arachidic acid, is in Phase 2 development for the treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).
    • There is a first-to-market horse race among drug developers for a NASH treatment considering it affects ~5% of Americans. As many as 20% have a milder condition known as "fatty liver."
     
     
     
     
    | 11:30 AM | 5 Comments

  • Treasury yields drop to two-week low after Fed

    • Up as high as 1.73% yesterday, the 10-year Treasury yield has fallen all the way to 1.62% in wake of the FOMC meeting. TLT +0.9%, TBT -1.8%
    • This may not be a U.S. thing though - rates are really diving across the pond, with the yield on the 10-year German Bund today down a full 9 basis points to -0.08%, and Spanish, Italian, and U.K. yields off similar amounts.
    • Meanwhile Fed Fund futures aren't yet totally buying the Fed's near-promise of a rate hike this year. The January contract at 99.46 suggests about a 60% chance of a move before 2017.
    • ETFs: TBT, TLT, TMV, TBF, EDV, TMF, TTT, ZROZ, VGLT, TLH, SBND, UBT, DLBS, TLO, LBND, VUSTX, DLBL, TYBS
     
     
     
     
    | 11:13 AM | 5 Comments

    • Gainers: AVXL +25%. AEGR +21%. NEOT +19%. COLL +17%. WVE +16%.
    • Losers: GBSN -13%. XXII -7%. EBIO -7%. CRBP -6%. IMMY-OLD -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:03 AM
  • CZR

    Caesars +7% after offer to creditors of bankrupt unit

    • Caesars Entertainment (NASDAQ:CZR) is up 6.5% to extend on yesterday's rally after the company moved closer to sorting out its bankruptcy woes by pledging more funds along with TPG and Apollo Global Management to creditors of its operating unit.
    • Shares of the casino operator trade at their highest level since June off enthusiasm over the deal.
    • It's still choppy waters for Caesars investors with a crucial court decision due out on October 5, according to a warning for SA contributor Joseph Bonaccorso.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:07 AM
  • GOL

    Gol Linhas flies higher

    • Shares of Gol Linhas (NYSE:GOL) are up 8.57% as they continue their volatile trading ways.
    • SA contributor Bram de Haas noted earlier this year that an investment long or short in Gol Linhas is a bet on the USD/Real exchange rate.
    • Brazilian Real 1-year chart vs GOL's chart
     
     
     
     
    | 9:55 AM
  • SJM

    J.M. Smucker shakes off another bear

    • Hilliard Lyons upgrades J.M. Smucker (NYSE:SJM) to a Neutral rating after having the food stock set at Underperform. The capitulation by Hilliard leaves Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan manning the bear camp on SJM by themselves.
    • Shares of J.M. Smucker are up 1.08% to $137.79 in early trading vs. a 52-week range of $106.87 to $157.31.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:42 AM
  • WY

    Weyerhaeuser pops higher after Goldman touch

    • Goldman Sachs starts coverage on Weyerhaeuser (WY +4.3%) with a Conviction Buy rating and $37 price target (22% upside from yesterday's close).
     
     
     
     
    | 9:40 AM | 5 Comments

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers as of 9:10 am

    • Gainers: HTCH +166%. WCIC +37%. AVXL +17%. NVAX +13%. CAS +12%. GALT +12%. CNAT +9%. RHT +7%. SEAS +7%. FATE +6%. OTC:BSPM +5%.
    • Losers: JBL -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:18 AM | 2 Comments
  • HTCH

    Hutchinson Technology, TDK merger waiting period lifted; +167% pre-market

    • The waiting period required under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act of 1976 as it applied to Hutchinson Technology (NASDAQ:HTCH) becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of TDK has been terminated by the FTC.
    • Satisfies one of remaining conditions to successfully close the deal, which is expected no later than October 5.
    • TDK will acquire outstanding Hutchinson Technology common stock at a $4 per share level.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:01 AM | 23 Comments
  • ON

    ON Semiconductor higher on Morgan Stanley upgrade

    • Analyst Craig Hattenbach pulls his Underweight rating on the stock, with an upgrade to Equal Weight. The price target is lifted to $12 from $10 (last night's close was $11.78).
    • Hattenbach is less negative on ON given the upward bias to estimates, and he sees the Fairchild acquisition as adding $0.16 to 2017 EPS.
    • Shares +2.3% premarket to $12.05.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:30 AM | 1 Comment
  • SFLY

    Shutterfly defended at Cantor Fitzgerald

    • Shutterfly's (NASDAQ:SFLY) 12.4% decline yesterday on Amazon's entry into its business is overdone, says analyst Youssef Squali.
    • The company's scale gives it significant cost advantages and its customers have high switching costs, argues Squali. The impact of Amazon's move will likely be "limited" in the near-term.
    • He keeps his Buy rating and $55 price target.
    • Shares -1.5% premarket to $43.55.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:26 AM
  • RAD

    More on Rite Aid's Q2

    • Rite Aid (NYSE:RAD) reports same-store sales declined 2.5% in Q2.
    • Comparable front-end sales +0.1% and pharmacy comp down 3.6%.
    • Retail pharmacy sales slipped 2.5% to $6.49B due to decrease in same store sales.
    • Prescription sales accounted for 68.5% of total drugstore sales.
    • Gross margin rate squeezed 120 bps to 23.9%.
    • SG&A expense rate improved 40 bps to 22.1%.
    • Adjusted EBITDA fell 9.8% to $312.7M.
    • Store count: Wellness centers +355 Y/Y to 2,214; Total stores -11 Y/Y to 4,550.
    • RAD +0.49% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:40 AM | 9 Comments
  • BAM

    Brookfield Asset made a Top Pick at RBC

    • Brookfield Asset Management (NYSE:BAM) is upgraded to Top Pick from Outperform at Royal Bank of Canada. The price target of $41 suggests about 21% upside from yesterday's close.
    • Shares +0.75% premarket to $33.97.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:31 AM
  • WCIC

    Lennar in deal to buy WCI Communities

    • The cash and stock deal valued at $23.50 per share is a 37% premium to WCI's (NYSE:WCIC) close yesterday, and gives the company an equity value of $643M and an enterprise value of $809M.
    • The current plan is for Lennar (NYSE:LEN) to pay $11.75 in cash and common stock valued at $11.75 for each share of WCIC.
    • The deal combines two of the largest Florida homebuilders, and includes a portfolio of owned and controlled land by WCI totaling 14,200 homesites - mostly located in the Florida coastal markets.
    • WCI has a 35-day go-shop period.
    • WCIC +34% premarket to $23.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:05 AM | 1 Comment

  • Party continues post-Fed

    • Asia posted modest gains overnight (Japan was closed) post-Fed, and in Europe, German and France are higher by 2%, and Italy and Spain by 1.85%. The U.K. is up 1.2%.
    • U.S. stock index futures are ahead 0.3%.
    • The 10-year Treasury yield continues lower, down 1 basis point to 1.643%. Gold has added another $4.60 to $1,336 per ounce, and oil is up 1% to $45.80 per barrel.
    • ETFs: SPY, QQQ, DIA, SH, SSO, VOO, SDS, IVV, SPXU, TQQQ, UPRO, PSQ, SPXL, RSP, SPXS, SQQQ, QID, DOG, QLD, DXD, UDOW, RWL, SDOW, VFINX, EPS, DDM, QQEW, BXUB, QQQE, SPLX, SFLA, BXUC, QQXT, SPUU, SPXE, LLSP, UDPIX, OTPIX, RYARX, SPXN, SPDN, SPXT, SPXV, TALL
     
     
     
     
    | 6:49 AM | 25 Comments
